Award.AwardTitle: III: EAGER: Mapping Three-Dimensional Virtual Worlds

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Navigating in online virtual worlds is similar to searching the Web prior to the development of the first search engine. Users can find regions of interest to them through serendipity, by browsing or word of mouth, but they can only search the specific world they are on. This exploratory project investigates an enabling mobile crawler technology that can collect information across multiple worlds, and allows virtual worlds to grow in a distributed, multi-server, multi-platform manner. Of particular interest is content in 3D environments that is interconnected with the traditional flat Web. In this research explores strategies for gathering content from 3D environments and, using that content, gain a better understanding of how users are utilizing 3D environments and how they might benefit from more accessible, cross-platform search services. Crawling in 3D environments has many similarities with flat Web crawling but has additional constraints that may constrain how much content can reasonably be collected. The gathered data will further be explored, e.g., how frequently content changes in 3D environments and how users utilize linking in virtual worlds as compared to the linkage structures on the Web. In addition, this project investigates how traffic patterns in 3D environments are related to links, recommendations, and groups.

The research challenges in this project are:
(1) Gathering content from distributed 3D environments. This includes approaches for navigating around the 3D environment for information collection are explored, mapping the 3D environment space, analysis of the impact of additional information that can only be collected via interaction, and characterization of the additional information that is available through internal and external links.
(2) Gaining a better understanding of user behavior. Research focuses on investigating ways in which user linkage patterns are similar to, and different from, user linkages on the flat Web and whether or not avatar traffic can be used to identify sites of broader user interest that can be exploited by the search process.
(3) Supporting search across multiple platforms. The aim is to develop a 3D 3D object ontologies and a schema, similar to RSS, that will enable virtual world servers to more easily support sharing of their data with an external search service.

As 3D environments become both more prevalent and more diverse, the need for a cross-platform search service will continue to grow. By increasing the visibility of content across platforms and servers, this project will allow content creators to focus on creating higher quality 3D environment by providing effective search mechanism for finding the desired content in a large, distributed, virtual world.

The expected results are expected to provide foundations for exploring questions of how to discover and rank a wide range of content in virtual reality, mirror world, and augmented reality environments. By creating an open platform, this project will provide opportunities for more researchers to work in 3D environments. The database of regions, traffic, and linkages will be made available for downloading and analysis by other researchers. Research results, gathered data and the crawler will be made available as freeware via the project Web site (http://virtualworldsearch.uark.edu).

Project Outcomes Report

Principal Investigator: Gauch, Susan E. Award ID: 1050801

Organization: U of Arkansas

Submitted By: Gauch, Susan - Principal Investigator

Title: III: EAGER: Mapping Three-Dimensional Virtual Worlds


Content on the Web is increasingly presented using dynamic presentation technologies such as Flash, HTML5, and AJAX that challenge traditional Web crawling technologies. Of particular interest is content in three-dimensional environments that is interconnected with the traditional flat Web. In this project, three senior researchers and a team of graduate students from the University of Arkansas have explored strategies for gathering content from 3D environments.  They analyzed the collected content to gain a better understanding of how users are utilizing 3D environments and how users might benefit from more accessible, cross-platform search services.

We have achieved significant progress for three main goals outlined in the project proposal. The first goal, i.e., gathering content from 3D environments, was achieved using our intelligent crawler that collects different kind of data from virtual worlds. We crawled a large subset of Second Life data to create a dataset for testing and to get an estimate of the amount of each type of data available. To better support content collection, we explored how frequently content changes in virtual worlds. Based on our findings, we designed an efficient, co-operative crawler/server architecture. By avoiding redundant data collection, our approach greatly decreases the amount of data collected, saves bandwidth, and allows search engine collections up to keep up to date. For our second goal, i.e., gaining a better understanding of user behavior, we built and evaluated a social network of avatars from data collected from the Second Life virtual world. We studied the behaviors of the avatars as a way of understanding how users interact in virtual worlds. We compared the social networks of avatars in virtual worlds to social networks in the current flat web including Facebook, Flickr, LinkedIn, MySpace, Orkut, and YouTube. The network analysis showed avatars in virtual worlds behave similarly to users in other online social networks. The component analysis shows that, while several isolated clusters of avatars exist, the main network component contains the vast majority of the avatars. In addition, we studied how users utilize linking in virtual worlds as compared to the linkage structures on the Web.  We found that there are fewer links between places and in virtual worlds is different, which could make content discovery with a traditional crawler more difficult since the navigation can only be done by in-world movement. Finally, i.e., providing a data set for further exploration, we made our data set and crawler software available on our project website for others to use.

In summary, we have developed a cross-platform, extensible data collection process for 3D Web environments.  Our crawler has the ability to run over a period of time, comparing multiple snapshots and thus providing an overview of how quickly virtual worlds change. We developed a new service-oriented paradigm for virtual world content collection that is co-operative and greatly decreases the bandwidth, storage, and indexing necessary to support distributed virtual world search. This collaborative approach could be used to direct the crawler to focus on unvisited regions or a region in the virtual world that has a high rate of change.  We have collected and shared a snapshot of data for a large virtual world, a useful resource for ourselves and others.
